patient_intake.narrative:
Virtual Consult MD
Intake Document

November 4, 2025 â€¢ Owensboro

DEMOGRAPHICS
What is your first name?
Amanda

What is your last name?
Johnson

What is your date of birth?
1995-09-03

What is your gender identity?
female

What are your pronouns?
she/her

PRIMARY CONCERNS
Top concerns?
Anxiety and worry, Social anxiety, Health anxiety (worry about having serious illness), Checking behaviors, Difficulty with uncertainty

When did these concerns start?
Anxiety has been present since teenage years but has gotten much worse in the past 18 months

Triggers?
Social situations (parties, meetings, dating), Health symptoms or doctor appointments, Making decisions, Uncertainty about the future, Being the center of attention

CONTACT INFORMATION
What is your phone number?
(270) 555-2947

What is your email address?
a.johnson.teacher@email.com

Emergency Contact Name?
Lisa Johnson

Relationship?
Mother

Emergency Contact Phone?
(270) 555-2948

INSURANCE
What type of insurance do you have?
private (teacher's health insurance)

MEDICATION ALLERGIES
Do you have any medication allergies?
No

CURRENT MEDICATIONS
Medication name?
Birth control

PAST PSYCHIATRIC MEDICATIONS
None - never been on psychiatric medication before

MEDICAL CONDITIONS
No major medical conditions, though I worry a lot about developing serious illnesses

SAFETY ASSESSMENT
Current suicidal thoughts?
No

Thoughts of harming others?
No

Currently safe?
Yes

HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS
Do you have a primary care provider?
Yes

PCP Name?
Dr. Sarah Mitchell

PCP Practice?
Owensboro Family Care

PCP Phone?
(270) 555-6700

SOCIAL & LIFESTYLE
Current living arrangement?
Living alone in apartment

Relationship status?
Single

Children?
No

Employment status?
Full-time elementary school teacher (3rd grade)

Education?
Bachelor's degree in Elementary Education

SUBSTANCE USE
Do you smoke or use tobacco?
No

How often do you drink alcohol?
Rarely - maybe 2-3 times per year at social events, and even then only one drink because alcohol makes me feel anxious

Have you used recreational drugs?
No - too anxious about potential negative effects

FAMILY HISTORY
Family mental health history?
Mother has anxiety, grandmother had 'nerves' (likely anxiety, never treated)

TRAUMA HISTORY
Childhood trauma?
Not major trauma, but was bullied in middle school which contributed to social anxiety

Adult trauma?
No significant trauma

WORK/DAILY FUNCTIONING
How are symptoms affecting your work?
I'm good at my job and kids like me, but I worry constantly about parent-teacher conferences and being observed by administration. I spend excessive time planning lessons because I'm afraid of making mistakes.

How are relationships affected?
I avoid most social situations. Haven't dated in 2 years because first dates make me too anxious. Limited friend circle.

How is self-care affected?
Sleep is affected by worry, sometimes skip meals when anxious, check my body constantly for signs of illness

GOALS FOR TREATMENT
1. Reduce constant worry and anxiety
2. Be more comfortable in social situations
3. Stop excessive health checking behaviors
4. Feel confident enough to try dating again
5. Sleep better

STRENGTHS
- Caring and dedicated teacher
- Good at my job despite anxiety
- Close relationship with family
- Motivated to get better
- No substance use issues

clinical_intake.qaText:
=== CLINICAL INTAKE RESPONSES ===
Generated: 11/04/2025, 11:30:00 AM

## CHIEF COMPLAINT
Q: What brings you in today?
A: I'm tired of being so anxious all the time. I worry about everything - my health, what people think of me, making mistakes at work. It's exhausting and it's holding me back from living my life.

## CURRENT SYMPTOMS & IMPACT
Q: How are symptoms impacting your work?
A: Moderate impact - I'm good at teaching and the kids respond well to me, but I spend way too much time over-preparing lessons because I'm terrified of making mistakes or parents complaining. Parent-teacher conferences make me incredibly anxious. I worry for days before administrator observations.

Q: How are symptoms impacting your relationships?
A: Severe impact - I avoid most social situations, haven't dated in 2 years because first dates terrify me, have very few close friends because I'm too anxious to put myself out there

Q: How are symptoms impacting your self-care?
A: Moderate impact - anxiety disrupts my sleep, sometimes I'm too anxious to eat, I check my body constantly for signs of illness which creates more anxiety

Q: Current stress level (1-10)?
A: Usually 7/10, spikes to 9/10 in social situations or when I notice a new health symptom

Q: Sleep quality?
A: Poor - takes me 1-2 hours to fall asleep because I'm worrying, wake up early with anxiety

Q: Days missed from work in past month?
A: 0 - I never miss work, even when very anxious

Q: Describe your worry patterns
A: I worry about everything. Health is a big one - if I notice any symptom (headache, weird sensation, anything), I immediately think it's something serious like cancer or a brain tumor. I Google symptoms constantly which makes it worse. I also worry excessively about what people think of me. After any social interaction I replay it over and over analyzing what I said and convinced I embarrassed myself. I check my body multiple times a day for lumps or changes. I check that my apartment door is locked 3-4 times before leaving.

Q: How do you respond to physical sensations?
A: Any unusual physical sensation triggers immediate anxiety. Heart palpitation? Must be a heart problem. Headache? Brain tumor. Stomach pain? Must be cancer. I know logically this isn't rational but I can't stop the thoughts. I've been to my PCP multiple times in the past year for symptoms that turned out to be nothing, but I still can't shake the worry.

## DAILY LIFE & SELF-CARE
Q: Describe your typical day
A: Wake up around 6am, usually already feeling anxious. Check my phone for any messages I'm worried about. Get ready for work while mentally rehearsing my lesson plans. Teach all day - this is actually when I feel best because I'm focused on the kids. After school I grade papers and over-plan lessons. Come home, make dinner, then spend evening worrying about various things - did I say something wrong today, is this headache serious, what if I get fired, etc. Try to sleep but mind races. Takes 1-2 hours to fall asleep.

Q: How do you cope with anxiety?
A: Not very well. I avoid situations that make me anxious which provides short-term relief but makes it worse long-term. I seek reassurance from my mom constantly ('Do I look sick? Does this feel like cancer to you?'). I Google symptoms which always makes it worse. I check things repeatedly. None of these actually help but I can't seem to stop.

## GOALS & STRENGTHS
Q: What are your top treatment goals?
A: 1) Reduce constant worry so I can enjoy my life more. 2) Be comfortable in social situations so I can make friends and try dating. 3) Stop health anxiety and excessive checking. 4) Sleep better. 5) Stop avoiding things due to anxiety.

Q: What personal strengths can you build on?
A: I'm a good teacher and care about my students. I have a supportive family. I'm educated and intelligent. I'm motivated to change. I don't use substances to cope. I'm aware the anxiety is excessive and irrational.

Q: Motivation for change (1-10)?
A: 8/10 - I'm tired of living like this and missing out on things

Q: What barriers do you anticipate?
A: Avoidance has become a habit. Social situations genuinely terrify me. The health worries feel so real even though I know they're probably not. I'm scared medication might have side effects that could be dangerous (my health anxiety talking).

## DIAGNOSES
Diagnosis 1:
Q: Diagnosis code
A: F41.1

Q: Diagnosis description
A: Generalized Anxiety Disorder

Diagnosis 2:
Q: Diagnosis code
A: F40.10

Q: Diagnosis description
A: Social Anxiety Disorder

Diagnosis 3:
Q: Diagnosis code
A: F45.21

Q: Diagnosis description
A: Illness Anxiety Disorder

## TREATMENT HISTORY
No previous mental health treatment - this is first time seeking help

## MEDICATIONS (CLINICIAN-VERIFIED)
Q: Current medications
A: Birth control (oral contraceptive)

Q: Previously trialed psychiatric medications
A: None - this is patient's first time seeking mental health treatment.

## MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Q: Appearance
A: Neat, appropriate dress, good hygiene, appears stated age, somewhat tense posture

Q: Behavior
A: Cooperative, good eye contact though averts gaze when anxious about topic, fidgets with hands, checks phone multiple times during session

Q: Speech
A: Normal rate, somewhat soft spoken, articulate

Q: Stated mood
A: "Anxious, worried, tired of feeling this way"

Q: Observed affect
A: Anxious, mood-congruent, range somewhat restricted, becomes visibly more anxious when discussing social situations or health concerns

Q: Thought process
A: Linear, organized, some rumination noted, tendency toward catastrophic thinking

Q: Thought content
A: Denies suicidal or homicidal ideation. Significant health-related obsessions (checking for illness, analyzing symptoms). Social anxiety with rumination about social interactions. Excessive worry across multiple domains. Some checking compulsions (door locks, body checks). No delusions or paranoia.

Q: Perceptual disturbances
A: Denies hallucinations, heightened awareness of bodily sensations

Q: Cognitive functioning
A: Alert and oriented x4, attention somewhat impaired by anxiety, memory intact, insight good

Q: Insight
A: Good - recognizes anxiety is excessive and interfering with life, understands thought patterns are irrational even though can't stop them

Q: Judgment
A: Good - seeking appropriate treatment, making sound decisions otherwise

Q: Clinical Impressions
A: 30-year-old female elementary school teacher presenting with longstanding anxiety that has worsened significantly over past 18 months. Meets criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder with excessive worry across multiple domains, Soc ial Anxiety Disorder with significant avoidance of social situations, and Illness Anxiety Disorder with excessive health-related checking and reassurance-seeking. GAD-7 score 19 confirms severe anxiety. PHQ-9 score 8 indicates mild depression, likely secondary to chronic anxiety and social isolation. ACE score 1 (bullying) is low. Family history positive for anxiety (mother, grandmother). Patient demonstrates good insight and motivation. No substance use. Functions well occupationally despite anxiety. Primary impairments are in social/relationship domain and quality of life. Good prognosis with CBT and possible medication.

Q: Clinical Recommendations
A: Recommend: 1) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) weekly with focus on exposure therapy for social anxiety, cognitive restructuring for catastrophic thinking, and response prevention for checking behaviors. 2) Consider SSRI trial - educate about medication given health anxiety concerns, start low and go slow. 3) Mindfulness-based strategies for physical symptom tolerance. 4) Psychoeducation about anxiety cycle and how avoidance maintains fear. 5) Gradual exposure hierarchy for social situations. 6) Limit reassurance-seeking and body checking. 7) Consider group therapy for social anxiety once individual therapy establishes foundation. Follow-up in 2 weeks.

structured.clinicalImpressions: 30-year-old female elementary school teacher with longstanding anxiety worsened significantly past 18 months. Meets criteria for GAD (excessive worry multiple domains), Social Anxiety Disorder (significant avoidance), and Illness Anxiety Disorder (excessive health checking/reassurance-seeking). GAD-7 19 confirms severe anxiety. PHQ-9 8 mild depression, likely secondary to chronic anxiety and isolation. ACE score 1 (bullying) low. Family history positive for anxiety. Good insight and motivation. No substance use. Functions well occupationally despite anxiety. Primary impairments in social/relationship domain and quality of life. Good prognosis with CBT and possible medication.
structured.clinicalRecommendations: 1) CBT weekly - exposure therapy for social anxiety, cognitive restructuring, response prevention for checking. 2) Consider SSRI - educate given health anxiety, start low/slow. 3) Mindfulness for physical symptom tolerance. 4) Psychoeducation about anxiety cycle and avoidance. 5) Gradual exposure hierarchy for social situations. 6) Limit reassurance-seeking and checking. 7) Consider group therapy for social anxiety after individual foundation. Follow-up 2 weeks.

phq9.title: PHQ-9 (Patient Health Questionnaire-9)

responses.question: Little interest or pleasure in doing things
Trouble falling/staying asleep, or sleeping too much
Feeling tired or having little energy

phq9.interpretation: Score of 8 indicates mild depression, likely secondary to chronic anxiety and social isolation. Patient's primary concern is anxiety rather than depression.

gad7.title: GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7)

responses.question: Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge
Not being able to stop or control worrying
Worrying too much about different things
Being so restless that it's hard to sit still
Feeling afraid as if something awful might happen

gad7.interpretation: Score of 19 indicates severe generalized anxiety disorder. Patient endorses near-daily anxiety, inability to control worry, excessive worry across domains, difficulty relaxing, restlessness, irritability, and sense of impending doom.

ace.title: ACE (Adverse Childhood Experiences)

responses.question: Emotional neglect
responses.answer: Yes - experienced significant bullying in middle school that contributed to social anxiety

ace.interpretation: ACE score of 1 indicates low childhood adversity. Patient's primary adverse experience was bullying in middle school which likely contributed to development of social anxiety. Otherwise had stable, supportive home environment.
